content: The "Homeless Veterans Prevention Act of 2017" authorizes per diem payments for care of dependents of homeless veterans and partnerships with public and private entities to provide legal services to homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness. The "Homeless Veterans Prevention Act of 2017" authorizes partnerships with public and private entities to provide legal services to homeless veterans and veterans at risk of homelessness, ensuring equitable distribution across various geographic regions. The Secretary will ensure partnerships with entities across the US, including rural communities and tribal lands, to provide legal services related to housing for homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness. Legal services for homeless veterans and those at risk include housing-related legal aid, family law assistance, income support help, and criminal defense for issues like outstanding warrants and driver's license revocation to reduce recidivism. Legal services for homeless veterans and those at risk include assistance in obtaining public benefits, criminal defense for issues like outstanding warrants and driver's license revocation, and other legal services deemed necessary by the Secretary. The Secretary is required to consult with public and private entities to identify and coordinate outreach relationships with relevant organizations. The Secretary must consult with public and private entities to identify organizations and coordinate outreach relationships for legal services provided to homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness. Entities in partnerships may be required to submit periodic reports on the services provided. Expansion of Department of Veterans Affairs authority to provide dental care to homeless veterans. Expansion of Department of Veterans Affairs authority to provide dental care to homeless veterans. Subsection (b) of section 2062 of title 38, United States Code, is amended to extend eligibility for care to veterans enrolled under section 1705(a) receiving assistance under section 8(o) of the United States Housing Act of 1937 or care in specified settings for 60 consecutive days. The Department of Veterans Affairs can provide dental care to homeless veterans in various settings for 60 consecutive days, including therapeutic residences, community care coordinated by the Secretary, and settings funded by grants. The Secretary can overlook breaks in care not caused by the veteran. SEC. 5 amends Section 2023 of title 38, United States Code by removing subsection (d) and redesignating subsection (e) as subsection (d). SEC. 6 extends the authority for financial assistance for supportive services for very low-income veteran families in permanent housing. Section 2023 of title 38, United States Code is amended by removing subsection (d) and redesignating subsection (e) as subsection (d). Additionally, the authority for financial assistance for supportive services for very low-income veteran families in permanent housing is extended. The Comptroller General of the United States will study Department of Veterans Affairs programs for homeless veterans within 270 days of this Act. The study will assess program effectiveness and review efforts to improve privacy, safety, and security for female veterans. Additionally, the requirement for annual reports on assistance to homeless veterans is repealed. SEC. 8. REPEAL OF REQUIREMENT FOR ANNUAL REPORTS ON ASSISTANCE TO HOMELESS VETERANS. Section 2065 of title 38, United States Code, is repealed. The table of sections in chapter 20 of such title is amended accordingly.
